COVID-19 ZOA - YMCA Community-based Sociotherapy & Liberia Peacebuilding Office

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sveriges ambassad i Monrovia har mottagit en förfrågan från ZOA angående stöd till projektet "Peacebuilding and Reconciliation through Community Dialogues: Strengthening Social Cohesion and Civic Trust in Five Counties, Liberia" för perioden 2017 - 2020. Insatsen innebär att utföra den evidensbaserade metoden "Community-based social therapy", en form av social gruppterapi för byar. Målet med sessionerna är att bygga förtroende mellan deltagarna och att lära ut verktyg för hur att hantera svåra minnen och traumatiska upplevelser från kriget samt verktyg för konfliktlösning och kommunikation. Det finns positiva resultat från bland annat Rwanda där modellen först introducerades. ZOA arbetar även med att utbilda och träna lokala myndighetsanställda och ledare från civilsamhället i CBS-metoden och faciliterar dialogforum för byinvånare och lokala ledare (statliga och traditionella). En del av programmet inkluderar även att engagera lärare och skolungdomar i så kallade "fredsklubbar".
Insatsen har som övergripande mål att bidra till försoning och fredsbyggande genom samhällsdialoger. För att åstadkomma detta arbetar ZOA med målsättningar på fyra nivåer: i) individnivå: förbättrad individuell psykosocial hälsa och välbefinnande; ii) familjenivå: förbättrad familjedynamik, inklusive ökad jämställdhet; iii) samhällsnivå: stärkt och förbättrad social dynamik från gräsrotsnivå, inom och mellan målgrupper; iv) medborgerligt deltagande och förtroende: ökat engagemang hos medborgare samt förbättrade relationer mellan medborgare och lokala myndigheter. Projektet har genomgått en pilotfas som utvärderats och visar att dessa fyra nivåer bidrar till konfliktlösning och försoning på lokal och nationell nivå.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sweden's Embassy in Monrovia has received a request from ZOA for support for the project "Peacebuilding and Reconciliation through Community Dialogues: Strengthening Social Cohesion and Civic Trust in Five Counties, Liberia" for the period 2017-2020. The contribution includes carrying out the evidence-based method "Community- based social therapy " which is a form of social group therapy for communities. The aim of these social group therapy sessions is to build trust among the participants and to communicate tools for dealing with difficult memories and traumatic experiences from the war, as well as proving tools for conflict resolution and communication. There are positive results from, for example Rwanda, where this apporach was first introduced. ZOA also trains local civil servants and civil society leaders in the CBS method and facilitates platforms for dialogue for community residents and local leaders, both formal and traditional. A part of the project also includes engaging teachers and schoolchildren in so-called "peace clubs".
The overall goal of the contribution is to contribute to reconciliation and peace building through community dialogues. To achieve this, ZOA works at four different levels: i) individual level: improved individual psychosocial health and well-being; ii) family level: improved family dynamics, including increased gender equality; iii) social level: strengthened and improved social dynamics from grassroots level, within and between target groups; iv) civic participation and trust: increased involvement of citizens as well as improved relationships between citizens and local authorities. The project has undergone a pilot phase that has been evaluated and shows that these four levels contribute to conflict resolutionand reconciliation at local and national level.

The intervention has outcomes at four levels. The first outcome focuses on the individual level: improved individual psychosocial health and well-being. The second outcome focuses on the family level: improved family dynamics, including more gender equal relations. The third outcome has to do with community level: renewed social fabric from the grass-roots, in and between target communities, identified by improved social interaction and reduction of tension between different groups. The fourth outcome looks at citizen participation and civil trust: improved citizen participation and positive engagement with local government. ZOAs pilot community based social-therapy intervention in Margibi County in 2015 provides evidence that these four outcomes contribute to conflict resolution and reconciliation at local and national levels.

description.narrative: Component 1: An end-evaluation of this project was finalized in June 2021 and draws very positive conclusions. The "Peacebuilding and Reconciliation through Community Dialogues" project has targeted more than 12 000 direct beneficiaries and approximately another 50 000 indirect beneficiaries in eight locations in Liberia. Thanks to the work of 116 trained and certified CBS facilitators trained by 8 trainers, along with workshops with community leaders, peace clubs at schools, and local authorities, the project has improved individual psychological health and well-being, family dynamics, gender equality, social interaction in communities and at schools, and local governance. At the individual level, 98% of CBS participants indicated that the sociotherapy had changed them as a person and 99% said that they had changed their behavior. People feel calmer, more confident, and have more self-knowledge, leading to better psychological health and a reduction in anxiety, stress, and anger. The therapy has also taught participants to deal with conflict differently, to communicate more peacefully, and to reconcile long-standing disputes. At the family level, CBS participants have improved their communication with partners, children, and extended families. While CBS participants still have conflicts and frustrations just like other people, they have learned to control their anger, to express their frustrations at appropriate moments, and to apologize and reconcile after a conflict. The therapy has also taught people to make decision-making within the household more inclusive, leading to improved family dynamics and more gender-equal relations. At the community level, the Community Leadership Forum and Civic Trust Workshops have given communities a new sense of civic engagement and have repaired inter-group relations and trust. Whereas religious leaders, traditional leaders, and other civil society groups used to be disconnected from the local authorities, the project activities have brought local leaders, peace clubs at schools, and authorities closer together. This has reduced tensions and improved communication between Christians, Muslims and traditional people, neighboring clans and towns, as well as peace clubs and women groups. Finally, at the governance level, the merging of the Community Leadership Forum and the Civic Trust Workshops has also improved governance. Thanks to the renewed communication and respect and trust in communities, relations between local leaders and the authorities are now more (gender) inclusive. Citizen participation has increased, and the authorities are engaged in a series of joint activities thanks to action plans that were set up in collaboration with local leaders. While many challenges remain, there is a growing sense that the communities will overcome them together. Component 2: A mid-term evaluation of this project component was finalized in October 2020. It's main conclusions are summarized below: The Early Warning and Early Response project is successful as an early warning mechanism, but not yet as a response mechanism. Similarly, it is successful at the district level, but not yet at the county and national levels. As a result of these dynamics, many local disputes are successfully mediated and resolved by local leaders, whereas response to more serious crimes and political conflicts is slow or non-existent. 183 Early Warning and Early Response (EWER) Volunteers and 204 County Peace Committees (CPC) have been successfully trained receive continuous support from ZOA and the Liberia Peacebuilding Office (PBO). Apart from some minor complaints about financial incentives, these local stakeholders have increased their skills and confidence in local peacebuilding, resolving disputes between citizens involving domestic violence, theft, and local property disputes, among others. Both large and small issues are also reported to the county authorities, as well as the national Liberia Early Response Network (LERN) platform. The authorities and County Security Councils (CSC) in many counties remain largely disconnected from local disputes. While County Superintendents, Police Commissioners, and Land Authorities at times intervene in border-disputes, land-conflicts with concession companies, or violent protests, the reputation of county authorities is oftentimes poor. Local leaders feel that the county authorities lack the capacity to respond to criminal cases, and that they care more about politics than about their constituents. Although the PBO has urged superintendents to allow CPC members to join monthly CSC meetings, few CPCs enjoy official recognition, and none receive financial support to pay for expenses. The PBO plays an important role in monitoring the LERN platform and forwarding information to the relevant ministries and counties to ensure a timely and adequate response to conflicts. Unfortunately, the PBO structurally lacks the financial and bureaucratic capacity to turn platform-data into effective peacebuilding responses. Monthly briefings are emailed to key stakeholders, including the National Center for the Coordination of Response Mechanism (NCCRM), but there is no data available on follow-up activities.
